Label: 250-msec cross track ion drift velocities - Rod Heelis (University of Texas, Dallas)

VariableDescription.Name: scVelocity
VariableDescription.Header:
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     TITLE                           DE-2 IDM 0.25-sec ion drift
#     PROJECT                         DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     SOURCE_NAME                     DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Magnetospheric  Ionospheric Interactions
#     DESCRIPTOR                      vion250ms> ion 250ms
#     DATA_TYPE                       idm>Ion Drift Meter
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TEXT                            The Ion Drift Meter (IDM) measured the bulk motions of the ionospheric plasma                          
#     TEXT                             perpendicular to the satellite velocity vector. The measured parameters, horizontal                   
#     TEXT                             and vertical ion-drift velocities, had an expected range of plus or minus 4                           
#     TEXT                             km/s. The accuracy of the measurement was expected to be plus or minus 50 m/s                         
#     TEXT                             for the anticipated 0.5 deg accuracy in vehicle attitude determination. The                           
#     TEXT                             nominal time resolution of the measurement was 1/32 s. This investigation yielded                     
#     TEXT                             information on (1) the ion convection (electric field) pattern in the auroral                         
#     TEXT                             and polar ionosphere; (2) the flow of plasma along magnetic field lines within                        
#     TEXT                             the plasmasphere, which determines whether this motion was simply a breathing                         
#     TEXT                             of the protonosphere, a refilling of this region after a storm, or an interhemispheric                
#     TEXT                             transport of plasma; (3) the thermal ion contribution to field-aligned electric                       
#     TEXT                             currents; (4) velocity fields associated with small-scale phenomena that are                          
#     TEXT                             important at both low and high latitudes; and (5) the magnitude and variation                         
#     TEXT                             of the total concentration along the flight path. The ion drift meter measured                        
#     TEXT                             the plasma motion parallel to the sensor face by using a gridded collimator                           
#     TEXT                             and multiple collectors to determine the direction of arrival of the plasma.                          
#     TEXT                             The instrument geometry was very similar to that used on the Atmosphere Explorer                      
#     TEXT                             satellites. Each sensor consisted of a square entrance aperture that served                           
#     TEXT                             as collimator, some electrically isolating grids, and a segmented planar collector.                   
#     TEXT                             The angle of arrival of the ions with respect to the sensor was determined                            
#     TEXT                             by measuring the ratio of the currents to the different collector segments,                           
#     TEXT                             and this was done by taking the difference in the logarithms of the current.                          
#     TEXT                             Two techniques were used to determine this ratio. In the standard drift sensor                        
#     TEXT                             (SDS), the collector segments were connected in pairs to two logarithmic amplifiers.                  
#     TEXT                             The second technique, called the univeral drift sensor (UDS), allowed simultaneous                    
#     TEXT                             measurement of both components. Here, each collector segment was permanently                          
#     TEXT                             connected to a logarithmic amplifier and two difference amplifiers were used                          
#     TEXT                             to determine the horizontal and vertical arrival angles simultaneously. The                           
#     TEXT                             IDM consisted of two sensors, one providing the SDS output and the other providing                    
#     TEXT                             the UDS output. Further details are in R. A. Heelis et al., Space Sci. Instrum.,                      
#     TEXT                             v. 5, n. 4, p. 511, 1981. During the period from 81317 to 82057 the instrument                        
#     TEXT                             memory suffered a critical upset and ion temperatures and drifts are not available                    
#                                      during this period.                                                                                   
#                                     This data set is available from NSSDC's anonymous ftp archive at ftp://nssdcftp.gsfc.nasa.gov/spacecraf
#                                      It includes the high-resolution data from the Dynamics Explorer 2 (DE-2) Ion                          
#                                      Drift Meter (IDM) for the whole DE-2 mission time period in ASCII format. This                        
#                                      data set was generated at NSSDC by converting the PI-provided data set (SPIO-00232)                   
#                                      from binary to ASCII format. The IDM data files provide absolute measurements                         
#                                      of the cross track ion drift velocity 4 times per second. The complete drift                          
#                                      vector can be obtained by combining IDM and RPA ion drift measurements.                               
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0241
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_vion250ms_idm
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 de2_vion250ms_idm_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      250-msec cross track ion drift velocities
#     PI_NAME                         Rod Heelis
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  University of Texas, Dallas
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00105
#     MISSION_GROUP                   DE
#                                     !___Magnetospheric Data
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Particles (space)
#
#              ************************************
#              ****  RECORD VARYING VARIABLES  ****
#              ************************************
#
#  1. NSSDC standard-reference time value.
#  2. Spacecraft velocity (geocentric)
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 22:51:28 2015
VariableDescription.VariableInfo:
#  2. Spacecraft velocity (geocentric)
#
TIME_SINCE_0_A.D.               V_S/C
dd-mm-yyyy hh:mm:ss.ms            m/s
15-08-1981 03:44:46.369       7404.52

VariableDescription.Name: ionVelocityZ
VariableDescription.LongDescription: Ion velocity in s/c z direction - vi_z - app. horizontal
VariableDescription.Header:
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     TITLE                           DE-2 IDM 0.25-sec ion drift
#     PROJECT                         DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     SOURCE_NAME                     DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Magnetospheric  Ionospheric Interactions
#     DESCRIPTOR                      vion250ms> ion 250ms
#     DATA_TYPE                       idm>Ion Drift Meter
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TEXT                            The Ion Drift Meter (IDM) measured the bulk motions of the ionospheric plasma                          
#     TEXT                             perpendicular to the satellite velocity vector. The measured parameters, horizontal                   
#     TEXT                             and vertical ion-drift velocities, had an expected range of plus or minus 4                           
#     TEXT                             km/s. The accuracy of the measurement was expected to be plus or minus 50 m/s                         
#     TEXT                             for the anticipated 0.5 deg accuracy in vehicle attitude determination. The                           
#     TEXT                             nominal time resolution of the measurement was 1/32 s. This investigation yielded                     
#     TEXT                             information on (1) the ion convection (electric field) pattern in the auroral                         
#     TEXT                             and polar ionosphere; (2) the flow of plasma along magnetic field lines within                        
#     TEXT                             the plasmasphere, which determines whether this motion was simply a breathing                         
#     TEXT                             of the protonosphere, a refilling of this region after a storm, or an interhemispheric                
#     TEXT                             transport of plasma; (3) the thermal ion contribution to field-aligned electric                       
#     TEXT                             currents; (4) velocity fields associated with small-scale phenomena that are                          
#     TEXT                             important at both low and high latitudes; and (5) the magnitude and variation                         
#     TEXT                             of the total concentration along the flight path. The ion drift meter measured                        
#     TEXT                             the plasma motion parallel to the sensor face by using a gridded collimator                           
#     TEXT                             and multiple collectors to determine the direction of arrival of the plasma.                          
#     TEXT                             The instrument geometry was very similar to that used on the Atmosphere Explorer                      
#     TEXT                             satellites. Each sensor consisted of a square entrance aperture that served                           
#     TEXT                             as collimator, some electrically isolating grids, and a segmented planar collector.                   
#     TEXT                             The angle of arrival of the ions with respect to the sensor was determined                            
#     TEXT                             by measuring the ratio of the currents to the different collector segments,                           
#     TEXT                             and this was done by taking the difference in the logarithms of the current.                          
#     TEXT                             Two techniques were used to determine this ratio. In the standard drift sensor                        
#     TEXT                             (SDS), the collector segments were connected in pairs to two logarithmic amplifiers.                  
#     TEXT                             The second technique, called the univeral drift sensor (UDS), allowed simultaneous                    
#     TEXT                             measurement of both components. Here, each collector segment was permanently                          
#     TEXT                             connected to a logarithmic amplifier and two difference amplifiers were used                          
#     TEXT                             to determine the horizontal and vertical arrival angles simultaneously. The                           
#     TEXT                             IDM consisted of two sensors, one providing the SDS output and the other providing                    
#     TEXT                             the UDS output. Further details are in R. A. Heelis et al., Space Sci. Instrum.,                      
#     TEXT                             v. 5, n. 4, p. 511, 1981. During the period from 81317 to 82057 the instrument                        
#     TEXT                             memory suffered a critical upset and ion temperatures and drifts are not available                    
#                                      during this period.                                                                                   
#                                     This data set is available from NSSDC's anonymous ftp archive at ftp://nssdcftp.gsfc.nasa.gov/spacecraf
#                                      It includes the high-resolution data from the Dynamics Explorer 2 (DE-2) Ion                          
#                                      Drift Meter (IDM) for the whole DE-2 mission time period in ASCII format. This                        
#                                      data set was generated at NSSDC by converting the PI-provided data set (SPIO-00232)                   
#                                      from binary to ASCII format. The IDM data files provide absolute measurements                         
#                                      of the cross track ion drift velocity 4 times per second. The complete drift                          
#                                      vector can be obtained by combining IDM and RPA ion drift measurements.                               
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0241
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_vion250ms_idm
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 de2_vion250ms_idm_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      250-msec cross track ion drift velocities
#     PI_NAME                         Rod Heelis
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  University of Texas, Dallas
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00105
#     MISSION_GROUP                   DE
#                                     !___Magnetospheric Data
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Particles (space)
#
#              ************************************
#              ****  RECORD VARYING VARIABLES  ****
#              ************************************
#
#  1. NSSDC standard-reference time value (ion velocity) Z direction.
#  2. Ion velocity in s/c z direction - vi_z - app. horizontal
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 22:51:29 2015
VariableDescription.VariableInfo:
#  2. Ion velocity in s/c z direction - vi_z - app. horizontal
#
TIME_SINCE_0_A.D._VELZ    VI_Z
dd-mm-yyyy hh:mm:ss.ms     m/s
15-08-1981 03:44:46.444    -68

VariableDescription.Name: dataQualityZ
VariableDescription.LongDescription: Data quality flag for vi_z (0-1: good; 2-3: averaging recom.; 4-5: unreliable
VariableDescription.Header:
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     TITLE                           DE-2 IDM 0.25-sec ion drift
#     PROJECT                         DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     SOURCE_NAME                     DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Magnetospheric  Ionospheric Interactions
#     DESCRIPTOR                      vion250ms> ion 250ms
#     DATA_TYPE                       idm>Ion Drift Meter
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TEXT                            The Ion Drift Meter (IDM) measured the bulk motions of the ionospheric plasma                          
#     TEXT                             perpendicular to the satellite velocity vector. The measured parameters, horizontal                   
#     TEXT                             and vertical ion-drift velocities, had an expected range of plus or minus 4                           
#     TEXT                             km/s. The accuracy of the measurement was expected to be plus or minus 50 m/s                         
#     TEXT                             for the anticipated 0.5 deg accuracy in vehicle attitude determination. The                           
#     TEXT                             nominal time resolution of the measurement was 1/32 s. This investigation yielded                     
#     TEXT                             information on (1) the ion convection (electric field) pattern in the auroral                         
#     TEXT                             and polar ionosphere; (2) the flow of plasma along magnetic field lines within                        
#     TEXT                             the plasmasphere, which determines whether this motion was simply a breathing                         
#     TEXT                             of the protonosphere, a refilling of this region after a storm, or an interhemispheric                
#     TEXT                             transport of plasma; (3) the thermal ion contribution to field-aligned electric                       
#     TEXT                             currents; (4) velocity fields associated with small-scale phenomena that are                          
#     TEXT                             important at both low and high latitudes; and (5) the magnitude and variation                         
#     TEXT                             of the total concentration along the flight path. The ion drift meter measured                        
#     TEXT                             the plasma motion parallel to the sensor face by using a gridded collimator                           
#     TEXT                             and multiple collectors to determine the direction of arrival of the plasma.                          
#     TEXT                             The instrument geometry was very similar to that used on the Atmosphere Explorer                      
#     TEXT                             satellites. Each sensor consisted of a square entrance aperture that served                           
#     TEXT                             as collimator, some electrically isolating grids, and a segmented planar collector.                   
#     TEXT                             The angle of arrival of the ions with respect to the sensor was determined                            
#     TEXT                             by measuring the ratio of the currents to the different collector segments,                           
#     TEXT                             and this was done by taking the difference in the logarithms of the current.                          
#     TEXT                             Two techniques were used to determine this ratio. In the standard drift sensor                        
#     TEXT                             (SDS), the collector segments were connected in pairs to two logarithmic amplifiers.                  
#     TEXT                             The second technique, called the univeral drift sensor (UDS), allowed simultaneous                    
#     TEXT                             measurement of both components. Here, each collector segment was permanently                          
#     TEXT                             connected to a logarithmic amplifier and two difference amplifiers were used                          
#     TEXT                             to determine the horizontal and vertical arrival angles simultaneously. The                           
#     TEXT                             IDM consisted of two sensors, one providing the SDS output and the other providing                    
#     TEXT                             the UDS output. Further details are in R. A. Heelis et al., Space Sci. Instrum.,                      
#     TEXT                             v. 5, n. 4, p. 511, 1981. During the period from 81317 to 82057 the instrument                        
#     TEXT                             memory suffered a critical upset and ion temperatures and drifts are not available                    
#                                      during this period.                                                                                   
#                                     This data set is available from NSSDC's anonymous ftp archive at ftp://nssdcftp.gsfc.nasa.gov/spacecraf
#                                      It includes the high-resolution data from the Dynamics Explorer 2 (DE-2) Ion                          
#                                      Drift Meter (IDM) for the whole DE-2 mission time period in ASCII format. This                        
#                                      data set was generated at NSSDC by converting the PI-provided data set (SPIO-00232)                   
#                                      from binary to ASCII format. The IDM data files provide absolute measurements                         
#                                      of the cross track ion drift velocity 4 times per second. The complete drift                          
#                                      vector can be obtained by combining IDM and RPA ion drift measurements.                               
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0241
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_vion250ms_idm
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 de2_vion250ms_idm_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      250-msec cross track ion drift velocities
#     PI_NAME                         Rod Heelis
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  University of Texas, Dallas
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00105
#     MISSION_GROUP                   DE
#                                     !___Magnetospheric Data
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Particles (space)
#
#              ************************************
#              ****  RECORD VARYING VARIABLES  ****
#              ************************************
#
#  1. NSSDC standard-reference time value (ion velocity) Z direction.
#  2. Data quality flag for vi_z (0-1: good; 2-3: averaging recom.; 4-5: unreliable
#       NOTES:  0-1: Ni < 2.E4 cm-3 velocity measurements are good; 2-3: 2.0E4 > Ni >  7.0E3 cm-3 averaging several data points is recommended; 4-5: Ni < 7.0E3 cm-3 data are unreliable.
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 22:51:29 2015
VariableDescription.VariableInfo:
#       NOTES:  0-1: Ni < 2.E4 cm-3 velocity measurements are good; 2-3: 2.0E4 > Ni >  7.0E3 cm-3 averaging several data points is recommended; 4-5: Ni < 7.0E3 cm-3 data are unreliable.

dd-mm-yyyy hh:mm:ss.ms                   
15-08-1981 03:44:46.444                 0

VariableDescription.Name: ionVelocityY
VariableDescription.LongDescription: Ion velocity in s/c y direction - vi_y - app. vertical (>0 upward)
VariableDescription.Header:
#              ************************************
#              *****    GLOBAL ATTRIBUTES    ******
#              ************************************
#
#     TITLE                           DE-2 IDM 0.25-sec ion drift
#     PROJECT                         DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     SOURCE_NAME                     DE>Dynamics Explorer
#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Magnetospheric  Ionospheric Interactions
#     DESCRIPTOR                      vion250ms> ion 250ms
#     DATA_TYPE                       idm>Ion Drift Meter
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TEXT                            The Ion Drift Meter (IDM) measured the bulk motions of the ionospheric plasma                          
#     TEXT                             perpendicular to the satellite velocity vector. The measured parameters, horizontal                   
#     TEXT                             and vertical ion-drift velocities, had an expected range of plus or minus 4                           
#     TEXT                             km/s. The accuracy of the measurement was expected to be plus or minus 50 m/s                         
#     TEXT                             for the anticipated 0.5 deg accuracy in vehicle attitude determination. The                           
#     TEXT                             nominal time resolution of the measurement was 1/32 s. This investigation yielded                     
#     TEXT                             information on (1) the ion convection (electric field) pattern in the auroral                         
#     TEXT                             and polar ionosphere; (2) the flow of plasma along magnetic field lines within                        
#     TEXT                             the plasmasphere, which determines whether this motion was simply a breathing                         
#     TEXT                             of the protonosphere, a refilling of this region after a storm, or an interhemispheric                
#     TEXT                             transport of plasma; (3) the thermal ion contribution to field-aligned electric                       
#     TEXT                             currents; (4) velocity fields associated with small-scale phenomena that are                          
#     TEXT                             important at both low and high latitudes; and (5) the magnitude and variation                         
#     TEXT                             of the total concentration along the flight path. The ion drift meter measured                        
#     TEXT                             the plasma motion parallel to the sensor face by using a gridded collimator                           
#     TEXT                             and multiple collectors to determine the direction of arrival of the plasma.                          
#     TEXT                             The instrument geometry was very similar to that used on the Atmosphere Explorer                      
#     TEXT                             satellites. Each sensor consisted of a square entrance aperture that served                           
#     TEXT                             as collimator, some electrically isolating grids, and a segmented planar collector.                   
#     TEXT                             The angle of arrival of the ions with respect to the sensor was determined                            
#     TEXT                             by measuring the ratio of the currents to the different collector segments,                           
#     TEXT                             and this was done by taking the difference in the logarithms of the current.                          
#     TEXT                             Two techniques were used to determine this ratio. In the standard drift sensor                        
#     TEXT                             (SDS), the collector segments were connected in pairs to two logarithmic amplifiers.                  
#     TEXT                             The second technique, called the univeral drift sensor (UDS), allowed simultaneous                    
#     TEXT                             measurement of both components. Here, each collector segment was permanently                          
#     TEXT                             connected to a logarithmic amplifier and two difference amplifiers were used                          
#     TEXT                             to determine the horizontal and vertical arrival angles simultaneously. The                           
#     TEXT                             IDM consisted of two sensors, one providing the SDS output and the other providing                    
#     TEXT                             the UDS output. Further details are in R. A. Heelis et al., Space Sci. Instrum.,                      
#     TEXT                             v. 5, n. 4, p. 511, 1981. During the period from 81317 to 82057 the instrument                        
#     TEXT                             memory suffered a critical upset and ion temperatures and drifts are not available                    
#                                      during this period.                                                                                   
#                                     This data set is available from NSSDC's anonymous ftp archive at ftp://nssdcftp.gsfc.nasa.gov/spacecraf
#                                      It includes the high-resolution data from the Dynamics Explorer 2 (DE-2) Ion                          
#                                      Drift Meter (IDM) for the whole DE-2 mission time period in ASCII format. This                        
#                                      data set was generated at NSSDC by converting the PI-provided data set (SPIO-00232)                   
#                                      from binary to ASCII format. The IDM data files provide absolute measurements                         
#                                      of the cross track ion drift velocity 4 times per second. The complete drift                          
#                                      vector can be obtained by combining IDM and RPA ion drift measurements.                               
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0241
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_vion250ms_idm

#     DISCIPLINE                      Space Physics>Magnetospheric  Ionospheric Interactions
#     DESCRIPTOR                      vion250ms> ion 250ms
#     DATA_TYPE                       idm>Ion Drift Meter
#     DATA_VERSION                    1
#     TEXT                            The Ion Drift Meter (IDM) measured the bulk motions of the ionospheric plasma                          
#     TEXT                             perpendicular to the satellite velocity vector. The measured parameters, horizontal                   
#     TEXT                             and vertical ion-drift velocities, had an expected range of plus or minus 4                           
#     TEXT                             km/s. The accuracy of the measurement was expected to be plus or minus 50 m/s                         
#     TEXT                             for the anticipated 0.5 deg accuracy in vehicle attitude determination. The                           
#     TEXT                             nominal time resolution of the measurement was 1/32 s. This investigation yielded                     
#     TEXT                             information on (1) the ion convection (electric field) pattern in the auroral                         
#     TEXT                             and polar ionosphere; (2) the flow of plasma along magnetic field lines within                        
#     TEXT                             the plasmasphere, which determines whether this motion was simply a breathing                         
#     TEXT                             of the protonosphere, a refilling of this region after a storm, or an interhemispheric                
#     TEXT                             transport of plasma; (3) the thermal ion contribution to field-aligned electric                       
#     TEXT                             currents; (4) velocity fields associated with small-scale phenomena that are                          
#     TEXT                             important at both low and high latitudes; and (5) the magnitude and variation                         
#     TEXT                             of the total concentration along the flight path. The ion drift meter measured                        
#     TEXT                             the plasma motion parallel to the sensor face by using a gridded collimator                           
#     TEXT                             and multiple collectors to determine the direction of arrival of the plasma.                          
#     TEXT                             The instrument geometry was very similar to that used on the Atmosphere Explorer                      
#     TEXT                             satellites. Each sensor consisted of a square entrance aperture that served                           
#     TEXT                             as collimator, some electrically isolating grids, and a segmented planar collector.                   
#     TEXT                             The angle of arrival of the ions with respect to the sensor was determined                            
#     TEXT                             by measuring the ratio of the currents to the different collector segments,                           
#     TEXT                             and this was done by taking the difference in the logarithms of the current.                          
#     TEXT                             Two techniques were used to determine this ratio. In the standard drift sensor                        
#     TEXT                             (SDS), the collector segments were connected in pairs to two logarithmic amplifiers.                  
#     TEXT                             The second technique, called the univeral drift sensor (UDS), allowed simultaneous                    
#     TEXT                             measurement of both components. Here, each collector segment was permanently                          
#     TEXT                             connected to a logarithmic amplifier and two difference amplifiers were used                          
#     TEXT                             to determine the horizontal and vertical arrival angles simultaneously. The                           
#     TEXT                             IDM consisted of two sensors, one providing the SDS output and the other providing                    
#     TEXT                             the UDS output. Further details are in R. A. Heelis et al., Space Sci. Instrum.,                      
#     TEXT                             v. 5, n. 4, p. 511, 1981. During the period from 81317 to 82057 the instrument                        
#     TEXT                             memory suffered a critical upset and ion temperatures and drifts are not available                    
#                                      during this period.                                                                                   
#                                     This data set is available from NSSDC's anonymous ftp archive at ftp://nssdcftp.gsfc.nasa.gov/spacecraf
#                                      It includes the high-resolution data from the Dynamics Explorer 2 (DE-2) Ion                          
#                                      Drift Meter (IDM) for the whole DE-2 mission time period in ASCII format. This                        
#                                      data set was generated at NSSDC by converting the PI-provided data set (SPIO-00232)                   
#                                      from binary to ASCII format. The IDM data files provide absolute measurements                         
#                                      of the cross track ion drift velocity 4 times per second. The complete drift                          
#                                      vector can be obtained by combining IDM and RPA ion drift measurements.                               
#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0241
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_vion250ms_idm
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 de2_vion250ms_idm_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      250-msec cross track ion drift velocities
#     PI_NAME                         Rod Heelis
#     PI_AFFILIATION                  University of Texas, Dallas
#     NSSDC_ID                        SPIO-00105
#     MISSION_GROUP                   DE
#                                     !___Magnetospheric Data
#                                     !___ITM Data including Earth Imaging and Ground-Based
#     INSTRUMENT_TYPE                 Particles (space)
#
#              ************************************
#              ****  RECORD VARYING VARIABLES  ****
#              ************************************
#
#  1. NSSDC standard-reference time value.
#  2. Geographic Latitude in degrees
#
#  
# Key Parameter and Survey data (labels K0,K1,K2) are preliminary browse data.
# Generated by CDAWeb on: Thu Jan 15 22:51:31 2015
VariableDescription.VariableInfo:
#  2. Geographic Latitude in degrees
#
TIME_SINCE_0_A.D.       GEOG_LATITUDE
dd-mm-yyyy hh:mm:ss.ms            deg
15-08-1981 03:44:46.369       52.2600

#     ADID_REF                        NSSD0241
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE                  de2_vion250ms_idm
#     LOGICAL_FILE_ID                 de2_vion250ms_idm_00000000_v01
#     LOGICAL_SOURCE_DESCRIPTION      250-msec cross track ion drift velocities
#     PI_NAME                         Rod Heelis

#     TEXT                             and vertical ion-drift velocities, had an expected range of plus or minus 4

#     TEXT                             for the anticipated 0.5 deg accuracy in vehicle attitude determination. The

#     TEXT                             as collimator, some electrically isolating grids, and a segmented planar collector.                   
#     TEXT                             The angle of arrival of the ions with respect to the sensor was determined
